{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3299488,"name":"BB3539","username":"BB3539","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bb3539/{size}/131284_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-01T15:26:12.496Z","cooked":"

Hello, we’re looking to use a ratching mechanism for the climber. I like the look and size of the WCP Ratchet Plate (1/2" Hex) (WCP-0585), however, if this is mounted onto the frame with the climber axle running through it, it will do its job but then we are stuck with our climber arms all the way down at the end of the match making robot removal very difficult. Am I missing something? I don’t believe they can be reversed. Is there a trick to allowing the winch to backdrive for removal short of removing the ratchet plate at the end of the match?

Nope, are you sure you would be able to raise arms arms to begin with. We picked up a couple of them only to realize there was no release of any kind. They will work for tensioning something but thats about it. Im refering to the WCP-0585 mentioned above

Yes, we plan on having spring loaded arms with the winch rope already out(will not need to be unspooled) which is why I thought these would be perfect…Until you have to quickly and efficiently remove the robot following the match:)

In the past we have used flex head reversible ratchet wrenches from Lowe’s. It got zip tied inside a channel or frame member then after the match we cut the zip tie and moved the wrench out of the way to reset for the next match.

IMG_5723627×790 74 KB

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-02-02T13:47:17.138Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":245,"readers_count":244,"score":94.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":452912,"topic_slug":"wcp-ratchet-plate-help","display_username":"Mike Marandola","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/f/5/f5186e84be1aed63d46ddef50f4a995566349539.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11375,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1983N11"},"post_url":"/t/wcp-ratchet-plate-help/452912/4","custom_user_title":"1983N11","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3300211,"name":"Nick Coussens","username":"Nick_Coussens","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nick_coussens/{size}/231882_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-02T14:16:04.559Z","cooked":"

The WCP ratchet plates are great for tensioning, for example if you use string/cable on an elevator and want to be able to micro-tension the up and/or down strings.

For something like a climb, it has been popular to use an actual ratchet wrench that can be removed from a shaft after use during a match. What Mike showed above is an extra handy way to do it with a flexible or hinge joint ratchet wrench.

You may also want to check what ratio you are running on your climber, as you may not really need a ratchet if you have enough reduction + brake mode on your motor to hold the robot with little to no back driving to keep you off the ground well past the +5 seconds at the end of the match.
